result.execSummary:
The defendant Matthew S Barker was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possess/Illegally Obtained Prescription, an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 450.11(7)(h).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
Costs to be paid as a Condition of Probation.

  If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged/terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  Collection may include income assignment.

Agent to determine if there is any need for treatment/counseling.
Defense counsel will provide letter within 7 days, letting the court know of any days of credit.

Defendant Matthew S Barker in court with attorney Robert Buckett.   District Attorney's Office Law Intern appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Defendant has now completed drug treatment court and the state amends count 1 to a misdemeanor charge. Court imposed the following sentence:

  The Defendant was sentenced to the following:

IMPOSED AND STAYED SENTENCE OF:   

4 months HUBER, w/Standard Release Conditions
 
TERM OF PROBATION:  12 months

CONDITIONS OF PROBATION:  
 Agent to determined if there is any need for treatment/counseling
